thread.title: Ready for the weekend? Here are New Orleans events for Jan. 24-26
thread.title_full: Ready for the weekend? Here are New Orleans events for Jan. 24-26

author: VICTOR ANDREWS | Staff writer
title: Ready for the weekend? Here are New Orleans events for Jan. 24-26
text:
After several days locked in the ice and sneaux (enough, Elsa!), New Orleans area folks are looking for some fun things to do before Carnival and Super Bowl usher in a new vortex of excitement. Stay warm. Stay tuned and stay active.
LPO and OperaCréole team up to present the world premiere of a groundbreaking opera Friday at St. Louis Cathedral. "MORGIANE" is the 1887 work by New Orleans native Edmond Dédé and is the earliest known full-length opera by a Black American composer. The performance is part of the Historic New Orleans Collection's Musical Louisiana program that includes a lecture at 5 p.m. at the Williams Research Center, 410 Chartres St., and the free performance at 7:30 p.m. Check out more information here.
The KREWE MOSAÏQUE takes its sophomore stroll through the French Quarter Saturday at 6 p.m. starting at St. Ann and Rampart streets, then heads down to Bourbon Street and turns left, takes a right at St. Philip Street for a block, takes a right onto Royal Street, a left onto St. Ann and another left on Chartres Street and ending at St. Philip. Look for subkrewes like Krewe de Mayahuel, Mondo Kaya, Krewe of Conus, the Weather Girls, Krewe of Heavenly Bodies, Krewe of Nyades and more. Scroll over here for more information.
It's a great day for Great Books, Saturday, that is, when the LPO Symphony Volunteers are at it again — this time in a POP UP BOOK SALE from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the group's new warehouse, 623 Distributors Row, Suite F, in Elmwood. In addition to a selection of fiction, history, religion and cookbooks, the volunteers will be selling artwork. It's a great way to break through the icy days of isolation and get some good reading material. Read all about it right here.
LOVE YOUR CITY AWARDS GALA celebrates local organizations for helping make the Crescent City have a sustainable future. Winners in 10 categories will be honored Friday at 7 p.m. at the New Orleans Jazz Market at 1436 Oretha Castle Haley Blvd. Big Chief Shaka Zulu will be the speaker, with performances by Saint Amethyst, Trumpeter Andres "Da Phessah" Baham and more. There's also an art auction by Young Artist Movement. Tickets start at $82. Check the festivities here.
Raise a glass when the Crescent City Homebrewers gather for WINTERFEST 2025, a celebration of the craft from 4 p.m. to 8 p.m. Saturday at Deutsches Haus, 1700 Moss St., New Orleans. More than 40 home-brewed beverages will be available at the "all-you-can-drink" event, plus live music. The $40 ticket also includes membership in the group. Raise a pint here.
The NOLA Project salutes Scottish author Robert "Rabbie" Burns with BURNS NIGHT, an evening of poetry, play reading and partying at 6 p.m. Saturday at Jacob Schoen & Son, 3827 Canal St. The local acting party celebrates the Caledonian wordsmith's birthday with food, beverages and an ensemble of players reading Gilliam Duffy's "The Ghosting of Rabbie Burns." Reservations are requested for the free event (a $20 donation is suggested). Take a wee gander here for more information, laddie.
After all this "sneaux-maggedon," everyone needs a good laugh and Saturday at 7 p.m., "HOPPED UP STAND-UP" brings the funny to the front at Urban South Brewery, 1645 Tchoupitoulas St. Hosted by Ryan Rogers, the funny folks frolicking on stage will include Brandon Haynes, J.Q. Palms, Pickle, Madison Thomas and Josh Watts. Admission is free. Snag a seat for the side-splitting sounds here.
It's ball season but this isn't that kind of a deb ball, it's the 610 STOMPERS DEBUTANTE BALL. At 8 p.m. Saturday, see the 2025 dance moves at the annual fête at The Fillmore, on the second floor of Caesars casino at the foot of Canal Street. The theme is "610 Movie Night: Be Kind, Rewind," and movie attire from the '80s and '90s is encouraged. Enjoy music by Johnny Sketch and the Dirty Notes, a costume contest and late-night pizza. Tickets start at $75. So get into that crop top and jeans or minisuit and thigh-high stockings and head out for the fun.
Head down to the Bywater and get in on the fun Sunday from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. for Bywater Bakery's KING CAKE CELEBRATION. The 9th annual festivity features a huge slice of local talent, including Soul Brass Band, Deacon John and John Boutté. And half of the proceeds from the king cake sales will go to the Ellis Marsalis Center for Music. Make your way over to 3624 Dauphine St. and bite into the fun. Take a taste here.
